description: SRE Dashboard for Trackly Backend - Structured top-to-bottom: SLIs ‚Üí Golden Signals ‚Üí Business Metrics ‚Üí Debugging. Each metric includes targets and actionable interpretations.

panels.description:
**What**: Application Performance Index - composite score of user satisfaction (0-1 scale).

**Why**: Single metric combining fast (<0.5s satisfied), acceptable (<2s tolerable), and slow (>2s frustrated) requests.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ >0.85 (excellent UX) | ‚ö†Ô∏è 0.7-0.85 (acceptable) | üö® <0.7 (poor UX).

**Formula**: (satisfied + tolerable/2) / total_requests.

**Actions**: If low, prioritize latency reduction. Check p95 latency and slow endpoints in 'Latency Breakdown'.
panels.title: Apdex Score (T=0.5s)

panels.description:
**What**: Percentage of requests completing within 2 seconds (performance SLI).

**Why**: Measures user experience - slow requests frustrate users.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ >95% (most requests fast) | ‚ö†Ô∏è 85-95% (degraded) | üö® <85% (critical).

**Interpretation**: Based on Apdex: <0.5s satisfied, <2s tolerable, >2s frustrated.

**Actions**: If low, check 'Latency Breakdown' for bottlenecks (DB queries, parsing, enrichment).
panels.title: SLI: Requests < 2s

panels.description:
**What**: Percentage of successful HTTP requests (non-5xx status codes) over 5m window.

**Why**: Primary availability SLI - measures if service works for end users.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ >99.9% (excellent) | ‚ö†Ô∏è 99-99.9% (degraded) | üö® <99% (critical).

**Interpretation**: Drop indicates backend errors affecting users. Each 0.1% drop = ~1 failed request per 1000.

**Actions**: If degraded, check 'Error Analysis' section for breakdown by status code and endpoint.
panels.title: Availability SLI (5m)

panels.description:
**What**: Backend service health check based on metric scraping.

**Why**: Primary indicator if service is running and responding.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ Always 1 (up) | üö® 0 means down.

**Interpretation**: Shows 1 if metrics are actively scraped from backend /metrics endpoint.

**Actions**: If 0, check: backend container status, logs for crashes, network connectivity to metrics endpoint.
panels.title: Backend Status

panels.description:
**What**: Percentage of HTTP requests resulting in errors, by status code class (4xx, 5xx).

**Why**: Part of Golden Signals (Errors) - identifies client errors vs server errors.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ <0.1% total | ‚ö†Ô∏è 0.1-1% | üö® >1%.

**Interpretation**: 4xx = client errors (bad requests, auth issues); 5xx = server errors (bugs, outages). Rising 5xx is critical.

**Actions**: For 5xx spikes, check backend logs, DB connectivity, external APIs. For 4xx, check if API changes broke clients.
panels.title: HTTP Error Rate

panels.description:
**What**: HTTP requests per second (RPS) by method and route.

**Why**: Part of Golden Signals (Traffic) - shows service load and usage patterns.

**Normal**: 1-50 RPS depending on time of day. Weekdays higher than weekends.

**Interpretation**: Sudden drops may indicate upstream problems or outages. Sudden spikes may be traffic surge or abuse.

**Actions**: For drops, check reverse proxy, DNS, upstream services. For spikes, check if legitimate traffic or consider rate limiting.
panels.title: HTTP Request Rate

panels.description:
**What**: Number of HTTP requests currently being processed (gauge metric).

**Why**: Part of Golden Signals (Saturation) - indicates concurrent load on the service.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ <50 (healthy) | ‚ö†Ô∏è 50-100 (busy) | üö® >100 (saturated).

**Interpretation**: High values suggest service struggling to keep up with demand. May lead to increased latency.

**Actions**: If consistently high, consider horizontal scaling. Check if specific endpoints are slow (see Latency Breakdown).
panels.title: Requests In Flight

panels.description:
**What**: HTTP request duration percentiles (p50/p95/p99) - time to complete requests.

**Why**: Part of Golden Signals (Latency) - shows typical and worst-case performance.

**Targets**: p95 ‚úÖ <500ms | ‚ö†Ô∏è 500ms-2s | üö® >2s.

**Interpretation**: p50 = median (50% faster), p95 = 95% faster, p99 = worst 1%. Rising p95/p99 indicates performance degradation.

**Actions**: If p95 high, check DB Query Latency, Track Processing, or Elevation API latency panels below.
panels.title: HTTP Request Latency (Percentiles)

panels.description:
**What**: Database connection pool state - in_use, idle, max connections.

**Why**: Part of USE method (Utilization) - shows DB resource usage and capacity.

**Targets**: in_use ‚úÖ <70% of max | ‚ö†Ô∏è 70-90% | üö® >90% (near exhaustion).

**Interpretation**: Stacked view shows total connections. If in_use approaches max, new requests will wait or fail.

**Actions**: If saturated, increase pool size in config or optimize query efficiency. Check DB Query Latency for slow queries.
panels.title: Database Connection Pool

panels.description:
**What**: Database query operations per second by operation type (SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE).

**Why**: Shows DB load and query patterns.

**Normal**: Varies with traffic. SELECT typically highest, followed by INSERT.

**Interpretation**: Spikes correlate with request rate. Unusual patterns may indicate inefficient queries.

**Actions**: If query rate high relative to request rate, investigate N+1 queries or missing batching.
panels.title: Database Query Rate

panels.description:
**What**: p95 latency for track parsing (GPX/FIT/KML) and full pipeline processing.

**Why**: Business metric - measures user-facing upload performance.

**Targets**: Parse p95 ‚úÖ <200ms | ‚ö†Ô∏è 200-500ms | üö® >500ms. Pipeline ‚úÖ <1s | ‚ö†Ô∏è 1-3s | üö® >3s.

**Interpretation**: Parse shows file format overhead. Pipeline includes DB writes, deduplication, POI linking.

**Actions**: If Parse slow, check file sizes and complexity. If Pipeline slow, check DB Pool Utilization and Query Latency.
panels.title: Track Upload Performance

panels.description:
**What**: Number of background tasks currently executing (max over 5m window).

**Why**: Shows async workload - tasks that don't block HTTP requests.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ <10 (low) | ‚ö†Ô∏è 10-50 (moderate) | üö® >50 (high concurrency).

**Interpretation**: Gauge metric, short-lived tasks may show 0. Using max_over_time to catch spikes.

**Actions**: If consistently high, review background task usage. Use /debug/background_task (ENABLE_DEBUG_ENDPOINTS=1) to test.
panels.title: Background Tasks

panels.description:
**What**: Database connection pool utilization percentage (in_use / max * 100).

**Why**: Part of USE method (Utilization) - critical resource saturation metric.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ <70% (healthy headroom) | ‚ö†Ô∏è 70-90% (approaching limit) | üö® >90% (saturated).

**Interpretation**: Uses avg_over_time[5m] for stability. High utilization causes request queueing and timeouts.

**Actions**: If >90%, increase pool max_connections or optimize query efficiency. Check DB Query Latency for slow queries blocking connections.
panels.title: DB Pool Utilization

panels.description:
**What**: Number of times enrichment queue reached capacity in last hour.

**Why**: Saturation metric - indicates backpressure and potential data loss.

**Targets**: ‚úÖ 0 (no saturation) | ‚ö†Ô∏è 1-10 (occasional) | üö® >10 (frequent saturation).

**Interpretation**: Queue full means new enrichment requests are rejected/dropped. Indicates enrichment can't keep up with upload rate.

**Actions**: If frequent, increase queue capacity or enrichment worker count. Check Elevation API latency for slowdowns.
panels.title: Queue Full Events (1h)

panels.description:
**What**: Rate of calls to external elevation API services (open-elevation, etc).

**Why**: Business metric - shows external API dependency and cost.

**Normal**: Correlates with track uploads needing enrichment. 0-10 RPS typical.

**Interpretation**: By service breakdown shows primary vs fallback API usage.

**Actions**: If rate high, check enrichment batching efficiency. Monitor API costs and rate limits.
panels.title: Elevation API Calls (rate by service 5m)

panels.description:
**What**: Total POIs (Points of Interest) created in last hour.

**Why**: Business metric - shows POI discovery and auto-linking activity.

**Normal**: Depends on track uploads with new locations. 0-50 per hour typical.

**Interpretation**: Counts new POI entities created when tracks pass through previously unknown locations.

**Actions**: If unexpectedly high, check for duplicate POI creation bugs. If 0 during active uploads, check POI detection logic.
panels.title: POIs Created (increase 1h)

panels.description:
**What**: POIs deleted or unlinked from tracks in last hour.

**Why**: Business metric - shows POI cleanup and deduplication.

**Normal**: Lower than creation rate. 0-10 per hour typical.

**Interpretation**: POIs deleted when no longer referenced by any tracks, or explicitly unlinked.

**Actions**: If high, verify deduplication logic isn't too aggressive. Check track deletion patterns.
panels.title: POIs Deleted/Unlinked (increase 1h)

panels.description:
**What**: Tracks identified as duplicates in last hour, by deduplication reason.

**Why**: Business metric - shows duplicate detection effectiveness.

**Normal**: 5-20% of uploads may be duplicates. Varies by user behavior.

**Interpretation**: By reason: hash_match (exact duplicate), spatial_temporal (similar route/time), etc.

**Actions**: If too high (>50%), users may be confused about upload status. If too low, deduplication may be too lenient.
panels.title: Tracks Deduplicated (increase by reason 1h)

panels.description:
**What**: Tracks deleted in last hour, by result (success/failure).

**Why**: Business metric - tracks user cleanup actions and retention.

**Normal**: Low volume, occasional user deletions. <10 per hour typical.

**Interpretation**: 'success' = cleanly deleted, 'failure' = deletion errors (referential integrity, permissions).

**Actions**: If high failure rate, check database constraints and logs for errors.
panels.title: Tracks Deleted (increase by result 1h)

title: Trackly: technical metrics
